title: Thursday, 12th April, 2018

BE11:05am

RESPONSE TO PRESS SPECULATION ON NORWEGIAN AIR SHUTTLE ASA

International Airlines Group (IAG) notes the recent press speculation that it is considering making an offer for Norwegian Air Shuttle ASA (Norwegian).

IAG considers Norwegian to be an attractive investment and has acquired a 4.61 per cent ownership position in the airline (minority investment).

The minority investment is intended to establish a position from which to initiate discussions with Norwegian, including the possibility of a full offer for Norwegian.

IAG confirms that no such discussions have taken place to date, that it has taken no decision to make an offer at this time and that there is no certainty that any such decision will be made.

A further announcement will be made if appropriate.

.... because Norwegian's a massive pile of debt and a nascent strategy to bring cheap long-haul to the masses.

Swedish Chef IAG offers LCC service at legacy prices. Nickel and diming customers is fine short term but it gets you in the end.

Norwegian did a share issue the other day that barely budged its debt ratios, which are still around 6x ebitda if I remember correctly.

Sails Indeed
BE11:13am

Too early for live comment, of course, but let me grab an old outliner from Davy ........

BE11:13am

We believe Norwegian is targeting a potentially profitable niche, namely leisure oriented, high density, long haul low cost from major European cities. However, for capital providers (debt, equity and leasing) to retain confidence in the Norwegian version of this, there needs to be an improving cost trajectory through H2 2018. Should Norwegian show that its cost of production can be compelling (revenue optimisation was always going to be backend weighted), which is no easy task, then it is game on.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The 1.3bn equity raise, with a further 0.2bn to follow in May, provides the
company with breathing room on its bond covenants, the strictest of which
dictates that the equity value must stay at about NOK1.5bn. Depending on the Q1
tax rate, we suspect the company came very close to this figure at end-Q1 given
the NOK4.18bn base at end-2017 and the pre-tax Q1 loss of NOK 2.6bn.
However, from here we note that each of the Q2 and Q3 periods since 2010 have
provided positive net income and we see this also being the case through the
summer.

BE11:16am

Despite the balance sheet support, we think there needs to be signs of an improving unit cost trajectory by year-end, when the company’s super rapid long haul expansion (90% in 2018) begins to slow, ahead of a more pedestrian 20% long haul growth in 2019, for all capital providers to find comfort in the project.

BE11:16am

So ........ high expansion but hugely lossmaking and terrifyingly high debt, with a few decent landing slots and an interesting strategy ......

11:16 am
BE11:17am

............. what does IAG want with this thing?

Blockbuster re IAG - clearly a defensive move. Stop a fast-growing threat on your key North Atlantic routes. Carve out the short-haul biz, sell it onto Ryanair giving them greater mass in Scandi.
BE11:19am

There's a cost story there, maybe -- I've flown Norwegian, as it happens. It was extremely good by low-cost carrier standards and I doubt they made a huge margin on my £9 seat to Spain -- but doesn't IAG have enough going on with Brexit etc?

DRichi I've flown Norwegian Air a few times. A cut above easyjet/ryanair and priced the same., and flying some interesting routes. Not sure about the debt, but could be a good long term investment
BE11:21am

And if (as @blockbuster suggests) the idea is to chop off transatlantic low cost before it becomes a threat ...... hello, CMA? Hello EU? Any thoughts?

DRichi I remember technical difficulties though, E.g. flights to Las Vegas being cancelled as their planes couldn't land when it was too hot

BE11:30am

Change of control on rail franchises, for one, which'd need government approval

11:31 am
BE11:31am

Also the debt, and the pension hole, and the difficult structure of the balance sheet that stops an easy separation of Greyhound and the rail stuff.

BE11:31am

RBC incoming.

Peace and Love @rw42 attempting to find any rational in DT's barrage of tweets is like trying to predict the flight path of a bat.
BE11:32am

The stand-alone share price has recently languished below the 2013 rights price - also with no dividend paid since then.
FirstGroup can now focus on existing shareholder value maximisation, as 5 year (rights to 2018) stand-alone market performance has arguably tested investors.
We find investors (pre bid news) were craving an updated strategy, and fundamentally significantly improved financial profit delivery. These were, we find, factors being required to see investors back the 'fundamental' value management seem to see in the group - but that an efficient market has (pre bid) not been willing to accommodate.
Should Apollo choose to walk away, there are presently no other confirmed or reported offers and the risk is the shares could sink back below 90p pre bid as there (1) remain value risks in the company (Rail contingent equity, pensions, UK bus outlook in certain cities, bus capex needs, Canadian Greyhound); and (2) fundamental questions remain over the company's inability to deliver on what is left of its last strategy, in our view. Our stand-alone PT is 95p.

Peace and Love rationale even
BornCynic Good tip on @MartianDTrump BE - do you think it's a journalist doing that? They appear to be the ones that are getting fed up trying to work out his policy from the tweets..........
11:33 am
BE11:33am

For the company to justify a higher share price on stand-alone basis, strategy and delivery thereon needs to improve (vs. track record) , in our view. For example, we find investors perplexed why FirstGroup has been embarking on debt refinancing without any guide of an updated strategy of what it wants to be. We find investors surprised that a deep re-think of its raison d'etre has not been used to guide the type and mix of capital structure it needs. • Absent a major strategic representation and refreshment of the group in the FY results (due 31/05/2018), we struggle to see stand-alone value in the shares sufficient to entice investors to dismiss a cash bid that incorporates a control premium - mainly due to the adverse American and UK bus EBIT dynamics seen since 2013. • However, at present the Apollo bid price is not known to us, but a sufficient control premium, a competing break-up bid, or a self break- up could, we think, see the company struggle to remain independent in its present form given the stand-alone equity track record.

BE11:34am

BE11:37am

Our initial view, in the absense of details, is that there are some key challenges such an approach wold need to overcome:

(1) the debt in the business (net debt last reported at £1.6bn excl restricted rail cash) and its long-term structure – a challenge if interest involves splitting up the group.

(2) £338m pension deficit

(3) Two new rail franchises that were won on full terms (growth expectations) and are only at their outset.

BE11:37am

Expect shareholder interest to hear more. After years of management struggling to turn around this group – expect shareholders to be interested to see the proposed terms flushed out, not least because of their reported cash nature. But our first view is that any approach won’t be straightforward for the acquirer. Perhaps that all explains the “highly conditional” nature of the interest.

Shinshin Atmospheric laser = tricky, because of ionisation and bloom. 50kg rock much more effective.
IslandDweller Even if you vapourise Assad (and I would shed no tears), you'd have the Iraq problem. The vacuum you leave behind - does anyone have a coherent plan for what next????
11:38 am
BE11:38am

And Liberum.

BE11:38am

We have long considered FirstGroup to be undervalued as recent poor performance has caused the market to overlook its leading or near-leading positions in all of its main markets. A takeover of the group would be far from straightforward, with UK government approval required for change of control of rail franchises and pension deficits to navigate around. Nonetheless, the approach ought to act as a catalyst for more urgent action by the board to crystallise value and/or for more credit for the potential value of the group being reflected in the share price. Our recommendation remains BUY with a SOTP-based TP of 125p.

Peace and Love @BE ;)

However, my understanding is that they were at least 2 or 3 days steaming away when ordered to move. Of course in the meantime, the anger subsides.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

SXX is offering an additional number of shares
equivalent to a 1-5% premium to parity which compares to the headline coupon rate of 8.5% pa. The CB matures in Nov’23 and there is an aggregate $308m outstanding. CB holders will also receive a mandatory “make whole” amount.

BE11:48am

Our first take is that the offer is opportunistic. The CB spot price is ~$145.2, which is trading in line with its intrinsic value (par value of $139.1 plus the “make whole” payment of ~$6.4). As such, SXX is essentially offering 1-5% upfront for a net interest saving of 8.5% pa (i.e. the CB coupon rate). For CB holders, they are giving up an 8.5% pa yield (for the next 5.5yrs) for what is now essentially an equity instrument, given the spot price of ~$0.43/sh vs. strike ~$0.31/sh.

BE11:48am

For SXX, the offer could result in a net interest saving, whilst at the same time, simplifying the
capital structure at an attractive price which, at the margin, could be helpful ahead of Stage 2 funding. However, in the short term it may result in share price pressure. To put this into perspective, we believe a reasonable assumption is that CB holders are, on average, 80-90% hedged. Assuming participating investors aren’t “natural SXX holders” it would imply net length of c1-2% of issued capital that may need to be liquidated per $100m of participation, or 1.5-3.0x average daily turn-over.

#REF! Putting a mine under a protected national park in Yorkshire, you cannot be Sirius...
Blank canvas pseudonym: don't forget the extra large pot holes for the buses to drive into
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Implications on CB holders: Whilst the premium is small vs. the coupon rate, the CB becomes callable from Dec’18 at an effective spot price of ~£0.38/sh (vs. spot £0.30/sh), which would attract nil premium, and there is also a risk of a “clean up” provision that would automatically trigger callability if the aggregate CB outstanding (currently $308m) falls below 15% of issuance (or $60m).

Sector trading was assumed to be terrible -- snow, etc -- and it's not quite as terrible as assumed. So, consensus isn't changing much but buyside had already priced in the worst, so is moving back.

BE11:59am

Here's Deutsche.

BE12:00pm

We do not expect a material change to consensus estimates: GNK guidance for £240m-£245m PBT
(consensus £243m, DB £244m; range £238m-£247m). Emphasis on investment and sustainable
dividend.
Trading
In managed pubs YTD LFL sales are -1.8% for the 49 week period (compared to -1.4% for first 37
weeks); implies -3% LFL in last 12 weeks but hit by snow in Feb/March: excluding the snow affected
trading periods, LFL sales are down -1.2% YTD (+drink, -food). Easter trading saw LFL sales +2.8%. In
tenanted pubs LFL net profit for the first 48 weeks -0.3% (+0.2% in first 36 weeks); Brewing & Brands
own-brewed volume was -0.7% (-0.9% for the first 37 weeks).
Other points
Cost savings of £40m-£45m for FY18E are on track to offset £60m headwinds; the additional £10m of
cost to support the investment in value/service/quality is now positively affecting trading; £160m spent on
capex on 292 pubs (in line) to maintain estate investment; disposals ahead of expectation at £120m (DB
£100m).
Valuation
For CY19E, 7.5x PE (7.2x EV/EBITDA) and c14% FCF yield before growth capital spend, with a 7.2%
dividend yield.
DB view
Despite slightly weaker, weather affected LFL sales, no material downgrade to consensus estimates
should comfort investors that: 1)Greene King can absorb tough trading conditions; 2) The dividend is
therefore sustainable; 3) The valuation is therefore too low.

Monju "Housing loan repayment through yearly growth" Trillion dollar can be invested with good return.
Miss Piggy No mention of crude busting through $70?
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Sorry about the lumpy formatting there. And here, with Citi.

BE12:01pm

— Given the recent share price weakness and an elevated short
position in the stock, we expect the shares to respond positively. We caution about
reading too much into the much improved Easter LFLs but weak LFL comps, the
World Cup and (perhaps) more normal UK weather conditions should allow GNK to
deliver positive LFL growth in FY19E (Citi +2.5%). Consensus PBT for FY19E is
broadly flat on FY18E reflecting ongoing cost pressures which seems realistic.
 Valuation & View — Buy. There are well understood sector-wide headwinds (see
here) but GNK is well positioned given its well invested freehold estate, prudent
balance sheet and strong cash conversion. With a FY18E PE of 7.5x, almost at
parity with the 7.0% dividend yield we see a strong valuation case and reiterate our
Buy. We retain Sell recommendations on EIGE, MAB and MARS given higher
leverage and weaker cash flow outlooks.

Miss Piggy (Brent)
